Feliz Martes! Mi amiga @eizagonzalez es nuestro último invitado en el podcast "Life Is Short"! 
Eiza is our first guest from Mexico, our first to physically record in our podcast studio, and our first guest who isn’t crazy about the muppets! (She has a funny/understandable reason for this)
We talk about how she came to be hugely famous in Latin America at a very young and vulnerable age, the psychological toll that took on her development, accomplishing the seldom-done crossover into American movies, and how much change has occurred for women since her arrival in Hollywood and how much more she hopes will happen (especially for Latina women). We also talk about how we met - on a field trip for @thisisabouthumanity -a great organization that brings supplies and cheer to kids and their parents stuck at the Mexican border (having fled unimaginable danger and violence from elsewhere in Latin America). Check them out + @yeswecanwf - they’re always looking for resources and volunteers :)
Hope you enjoy the listen! (In my stories or wherever you listen to podcasts 🇲🇽✌️)

20 years ago, I played precocious teen Warren on a TV show called “Ed”. I recently found some old outtakes from an episode in which @darylchillmitchell’s character helps #GinniferGoodwin’s character + Warren make a special meal for their friend. They reminded me just how fun it was to do that show + work w Ginny + Daryl - and how director Tim Busfield used to let us play and explore in a scene (you can hear him enjoying it but also reprimanding me for doing a little too much haha). After recently posting about @cavanaghtom being on “life is short” podcast, it’s been surprising and so nice to hear from people who miss the show. So this is for them - a little slice of why the show was SO fun to do and why it was a job I’ll always be immensely grateful for :) ❤️🎳

@ruffoibarra tests his teaching skills on an inexperienced + easily distracted @justinlong to raise funds for @thisisabouthumanity. special thanks to @thelittlemarket for matching donations 2-1. @thelittlemarket is a non-profit fair trade shop committed to upholding the dignity of artisans, celebrating their cultural techniques and traditions and bringing attention to social justice and human rights issues faced by their communities. Before covid there were maskless selfies and WAY before selfies, there was “Ed” - a TV show about a bowling alley lawyer, played by @cavanaghtom - my friend, my mentor and our latest guest on “Life is Short” podcast. I owe everything to that TV show (thanks @bonnieezane!) and most of that everything I owe to Tom. He and costar (and previous LIS guest) @itsjuliebowen set a shining example of how to act on camera and, more importantly, how to act off camera - setting a tone of professionalism and fun and gratitude that I’ll always try to emulate. It was a highlight of this quarantine to be able to do a nice long zoom chat with him - to reminisce about the olds days, to catch up on the new (his great podcast MATES w another Ed cast mate @michaelianblack and of course his hit show @cwtheflash) and to talk about valuable lessons his father imparted to him. Tom spent a fascinating part of his childhood in Africa and it’s a continent he often finds himself returning to w his wife @photo_mocavanagh as part of their work with @nothingbutnetsofficial - bringing essential mosquito netting to malaria ravaged parts of the world. 
Photos 2+3 are from their fun, romantic wedding 16 years ago - still the wedding to beat in my memory
Photo 4 is our “Ed” camera operator, Johnny Mac. Johnny was the behind-the-scenes heart and soul of that show. He was hilarious and mischievous and made going to work at that fun job that much more fun. He passed away recently and it’s impossible for me to think about that time in my life and not conjure great memories of Johnny. I just want his family to know how much his “Ed” family also misses him 💔

A year ago we recorded Grandma Jody’s episode of the podcast (ep 29 of “Life Is Short”) in Lake Worth, FL. I can’t tell you exactly what we were laughing about here, but I can say that few people make me laugh harder. Like most grandmothers, she’s very proud of her grandkids and (until she recently moved out) had a 32 inch box TV, which she’d sit 6 inches in front of and regularly watch Jeopardy, Wheel of Fortune, and every Hallmark movie ever made. On the stand that held the TV were Netflix DVDs she’d recently ordered and the copy of Accepted I’d given her however many years ago - making her, as far as I know, the oldest living S.H.I.T.head on record. I remain so grateful that she’s doing well and staying healthy at 103 years of age 😌❤️

I was lucky enough to spend some time working at a camp like @okizu, a camp for kids with cancer and the families struggling to keep them alive and happy (@campboggycreek in Eustis, FL). I can tell you how transformative that one week is for kids and for the counselors - getting to see kids stricken with a life-threatening illness (who normally spend all day in hospitals, hooked up to machines or hearing worried conversations between parents) just get to be kids and do fun stuff with other kids, out in nature, briefly forgetting problems that most of us adults never have to deal with. It’s amazing how important that one week is for these kids, how much more it is than just “camp” and it really breaks my heart that these fires took THAT from them. So for the next couple weeks, if you want to “hire” me on @cameo, all my $ will go there, to help rebuild. And if that’s not your thing and you have a few dollars you can spare, check out @okizu or follow the link in my bio. Thanks!

Living legend and Broadway royalty, Nathan Lane did our podcast by mistake! Download the latest ep of “Life Is Short” to hear the great thespian slowly realize he’s stuck in a conversation with me. I’m kidding- he was very forthcoming and generous with his time and his stories of growing up in a wildly dysfunctional family, how he made an on-the-spot decision to change his name from “Joe” to “Nathan” and how Mel Brooks cast him in The Producers while they were both floating in a hotel pool. I’ve long been a huge admirer of #NathanLane’s work - especially his star-making performance in The Birdcage -so, of course, we talked about that. And @poodollar72 and I wax “poetic” about our love of Robin Williams. P.s. I saw those twitter trolls come after you last night @zeldawilliams - don’t feed them - when I was fortunate enough to work with him, your dad was as kind and generous to me and the crew as he was talented - it was an honor to get to watch him. I’ll always respect and admire him deeply - the trolls are just out to provoke and hurt. Big virtual squeeze 😌✌️

I’ve always loved being a guest on @todayshow mostly because I got to have fun with one of my favorite “showbiz friends” @alroker. Well the fun tables have turned because Al is now MY guest on the latest “Life is Short” podcast - on which Mr Roker apologizes for laughing at my mustache on TV👆, explains how he became so fashion forward, lets me gush about his “Seinfeld” appearance and tells some fascinating and important stories about getting started in a VERY white dominated TV news industry in the early 70’s (and of course we talk about “Anchorman”❤️). I’ve known Al Roker as a warm, funny, ubiquitous presence in entertainment since I was a child so it was an honor to get to get to know him a little better - hearing his stories of perseverance and positivity in the face of some powerful obstacles was more inspiring than I would’ve imagined - And there are MANY more of them in his fantastic new book “You Look So Much Better in Person” (I recommend the audio book version to hear Al, with his great voice, read it the way it was written) 😌✌️

Like most actors my age, Phil Hoffman and Sam Rockwell were two guys I always looked up to - I was in awe of their work. One lucky summer, I was doing a play reading w Sam that Phil Hoffman was directing and I forget how or why exactly but at one point, Phil and Sam started jokingly wrestling on the floor of the rehearsal studio. Two of the greatest actors of my generation, rolling around like idiots and laughing - big, hearty laughs -both totally present and free, like kids (like the best actors are). Phil’s birthday is today and I can hear his big full guttural laugh right now. 
This isn’t the best quality photo but it’s still one of the best I’ve ever taken. I like remembering Phil this way and it’s just a good reminder to really appreciate laughing and acting like idiots with friends. I miss that. And I really miss Phil ❤️ #tbt

Fun fact: I was in “Anchorman”.
Sad fact: I got cut out of “Anchorman”
Fun fact: I got to work with Fred Willard (I played his rebellious teen son)
Sad fact: Fred, one of the greats and a personal comedy hero,  passed away recently. 
When I was on set, I was so excited to be surrounded by all these comedic heavyweights, that I did a very nerdy and borderline unprofessional thing and asked them to sign my script. 
Now, 17 years after that shoot, I figured this could do a lot better as an auction item to benefit @girlshomenica than it could collecting dust in my house. If you’d like to bid on this item and many others go to @celebrityauthentics (ALL proceeds from my items go directly to www.thegirlshome.com)

P.s. I only signed the script when @celebrityauthentics asked me to haha - not when I was a giddy 24 year old kid who was excited to have an acting job

Hoardy McHoarder is cleaning house and auctioning off some items I’ve saved over the years + 100% of proceeds are going to @girlshomenica - a safe haven for over 50 at-risk girls from Granada, Nicaragua (link in my bio) thanks to @celebrityauthentics! 

I’m a very nostalgic person - so every movie I worked on, I tried to hold on to one or two mementos from the set or, in some earlier cases, several pieces of my wardrobe. The first few years I was lucky enough to work in movies, I kept as much crap as I could (with permission!) - call sheets, SOCKS, a jumbo-sized prop cigarette from “Idiocracy”. The prop or wardrobe people were usually happy to oblige my weird nerdy requests, especially if the movie wasn’t high profile or ran the risk of reshoots or them making a sequel - hence why I saved so much stuff from “Jeepers Creepers” and “Dodgeball”.
After hoarding it for years, always thinking “I’ll give it to my kids, one day”, I decided TO give it to my kids... sort of 😌
Check out @celebrityauthentics for more items and @girlshomenica on more info about this special place. And thanks for your bids!

🎶 This is the Tom Green post, it’s not the green Tom post! 🎶 
If you didn’t watch MTV in the 90’s, you may have just thought I had a mild stroke - But if you DID, like my friends and I did growing up, then @tomgreen may also have been a big part of your comedic coming-of-age. Tom’s humor was brand new to me, at the time. It had roots in Monty Python and The Kids in The Hall -but the concept of interacting directly with people on the street, and creating hilarious chaos from everyday scenarios, THAT was new to me - and exciting and SO funny and, looking back, groundbreaking. Tom was kind enough to sit for a zoom with me where we talked about his own comedic evolution, the well-documented pranks he’d play on his parents, his (also well-documented) battle w cancer, his foray into the early days of podcasting and his regrets, his hopes, his mild annoyances. I really loved talking to him - I hope you all enjoy it too! You can listen to “Life is Short” podcast wherever you listen to podcasts - probably on the device you’re currently looking at :)

Stuart Cornfeld will be remembered by many as a producer who worked on movies like “The Fly”, “Kafka”, “Elephant Man”, “Zoolander”, and “Dodgeball”. I’ll remember him as a sweet, quick-witted, big hearted mentor - somebody who was very kind and helpful to me when I was a young actor. He was also responsible for some of my favorite comedy cameos - like this 👆a deleted “Dodgeball” scene where he played an unassuming and totally out-of-place member of Globo Gym’s team of ringers. I always just really liked being around him - he made me laugh and showed me that a powerful Hollywood producer could also be really kind and generous. I think I’m writing this because it’s stuff that I now wish I’d said to him. But even if there IS instagram in heaven, I’m pretty sure Stuart doesn’t have it 😌❤️

Outtakes w Mike White from a 2010 PSA aimed at overturning Prop 8 in California that legally defined marriage as being between “a man and a woman”. Josh Gordon and Will Speck made the ad whose tag line was “if straight people have to get married, so should gay people”. Prop 8 was, of course, eventually ruled to be unconstitutional - thanks ENTIRELY to our little ad. You’re welcome! As pride month comes to an end, I’m looking back in amazement at how far LGBTQ rights have come, just in the last decade - culminating last week in the Supreme Court’s decision that protects gay and transgender workers from workplace discrimination in the landmark civil rights act. Happy happy #pridemonth and so much love to my LGBTQ+ friends, family and strangers 😌🌈🌈🌈💪#fbf

Madre Albertina’s Girls Home in Granada, Nicaragua (the 2nd poorest country in Latin America) is a rare and vital haven for more than 50 social orphans to SAFELY get an education, proper nutrition, and a chance to realize their full potential. Most of the girls in the home either have no father figure or have very problematic ones - so this Father’s Day, if you book a @cameo w me (in bio) all my earnings will go DIRECTLY to the girls. It’s been so fun revisiting old characters I’ve done and leaving messages for fans, foes and probably some people who are totally indifferent to me on @cameo. 
Because of covid we had to cancel yet another trip to visit the kids at the home and fundraising (on which the sweet, selfless nuns who run the home rely) has stalled. You can also donate whatever you’d like by following the link in my bio. Thank you! And happy almost Father’s Day!

Our guest on the latest episode of “Life is Short” (wherever you listen to podcasts) is arguably the most influential comedic voice of the last 25 years and the man who brought the fake Beatles (The Beetles?) together; the great @juddapatow. Judd has done too much work in his career for me to have adequately scratched the surface but we do get into one of my favorite movies “The Cable Guy”, men who dye their hair, his creative muses: Bert + Ernie, and his innovative use of improvisation in his work (including in his wonderful latest film @thekingofstatenisland which can currently be seen on streaming platforms EVERYWHERE). Among the most joyful moments I’ve had as an actor over the last 20 years have been doing small roles in some of Judd’s stuff - as a viewer, he’s responsible for giving me COUNTLESS hours of joy and laughter. He’s also, on a superficial level, such an easy, enjoyable person to be around - so I loved getting to do that (sort of) during this socially distant time. 
1. Judd called me to play George Harrison during a time when I had put my phone away to be more present on a vacation. He had just given up on me when I frantically called him back. I came within minutes of losing out on, what would become, one of the best professional days of my life. That’ll teach me to try and be present on vacation!

Our guest on the latest “Life is Short” podcast is my old high school friend and former #1 ranked US men’s tennis ace, James Blake. James and I reminisce about Ms Dewitt’s math class, his thrilling US Open match against Andre Agassi, and, most importantly and timely, his own encounter with racially-motivated police brutality. In 2015, while waiting for a car to pick him up en route to a US Open event, James was standing outside his hotel in New York City when a member of the NYPD (in plain clothes) tackled him to the ground, put his knee in James’ back, handcuffed him and interrogated him right there for all to see. As EVERYONE now knows, the situation could’ve been gravely worse - James was lucky. And we’re lucky to have him as our guest today to help us have this vital conversation about race, the need for police oversight and transparency, and, more superficially, just to catch up and reminisce. I’ve always admired my friend for his humor, positivity and enviable athletic skills (especially since I have the tennis prowess of a toddler)- after hearing his story of determination in the face of a system that is rigged against him, I now admire him for SO so much more. Hope you all enjoy it and it sparks similar conversations with your own friends/family. Here’s to continued listening and understanding 😌✌️
“It’s like looking in a mirror” @poodollar72

Dear instafriends, 
Around this time each week, I post about a new episode of our podcast but I thought I’d share with you some other podcasts that I’ve been enjoying lately. *We love doing the podcast more than anything and are truly grateful to everyone who tunes in. Is “tunes in” the proper term? This is how new I am at podcasting (/how old I am, in general haha). We decided not to do a midweek checkin episode but will return this Tuesday when I catchup with an old friend from high school (who also happens to be a former #1 ranked tennis player)
I’ve been focusing this week on listening and learning - two things I’m not always great at - but these podcasts have helped immensely (and, far more superficially, they’re helping me w my podcast hosting skills 😏)
1. Code Switch...
This series aims to illuminate the ways race shapes our society. In this episode, host @jamilksmith examines police brutality against African Americans captured on video from Rodney King to George Floyd
“These calamities are so familiar, at this point, that their details have begun to echo each other” 
A fascinating examination of a deeply upsetting trend. 
2. American History Tellers...
I love history and think if we don’t learn from it, it’s bound to repeat itself - incidentally, that’s an original quote from me. It is! Anyway, the 6(?) part series about The Tulsa Massacre is as riveting as it is disturbing. To anyone who demands an answer to the question “why don’t ALL lives matter?” They do! But hearing about this grim episode in our nation’s history, it’ll really hit home the fact that, for SO LONG, black lives either didn’t matter or BARELY mattered. I was never taught about Tulsa or WEB DuBois and the groundbreaking publication The Crisis that @naacp published. Can’t recommend this series enough!
3. Good Ancestor...
Host @laylafsaad asks “How can I become a good ancestor? How can I create a legacy of healing and liberation for those who are here in this lifetime and those who will come after I’m gone?” She’s driven by this question and her passion and curiosity are infectious. I just discovered this but I’m really loving it. 
If anyone else has any recommendations, I’m all ears😉✌️

Very fitting that our “Life is Short” podcast guest on #givingtuesday is the MOST giving person I know, my dear friend and former Die Hard 4 nemesis @maggieq! Maggie is known for kicking ass in movies like “Mission Impossible 3” “Divergent” and the TV series “Nikita” and “Designated Survivor” but in life she TRULY kicks ass on behalf of animals and the underprivileged. Maggie and I talk about her fascinating journey from being food insecure herself on the streets of Tokyo to becoming one of the biggest action stars in Hong Kong, working together on Die Hard and being discovered by Tom Cruise and JJ Abrams - all of which has allowed her to pursue her greatest passion, protecting animals. She also tells me how that has lead to creating a line of really trendy (obviously don’t take my word for it) active wear made totally from recycled OCEAN PLASTIC (@qeepup) - and how her company is now selling tee shirts 100% of the proceeds from which go to @savethechildren. Yup, she’s a real asshole! As important as Die Hard was to me professionally, personally it’s one I’m deeply grateful for because it introduced me to this generous, funny, kind and TRULY badass bish (and slightly less badass but still bishy @lenwiseman 😘) p.s. do people still say “bish”? p.p.s. When people tell me they like “Strange Wilderness” (a critically panned movie that tanked when it was released 12 years ago) it immediately makes me happy. Maybe because I also like dumb stoner comedies. Maybe because it lets me know that the person I’m talking to doesn’t take themselves or their taste in movies too seriously. Or maybe because I’m transported back to the carefree, enjoyable experience of shooting that movie. Jonah and I were roommates at the time and we’d carpool to set together. We were both playing outrageous characters that we were given a lot of freedom with. I loved the smart stupidity of the script and had desperately wanted to work with Steve Zahn, one of my favorite actors. And the rest of the cast was terrific and so game. I think we all felt lucky to share scenes with the sweet, gentle legend, Earnest Borgnine (who I still can’t believe agreed to do the movie). There were so many moments throughout the day when the toughest acting challenge became not laughing during a take. Normally you know when a take has gone off the rails and is basically unusable, so laughing doesn’t really ruin anything - but this movie was so weird and unhinged that everything was in play - we were encouraged to act like the biggest idiots possible. It was a dream job. On the drive home, Jonah and I would usually still be laughing at something that happened on set or we’d listen to music, too tired from the day’s fun to laugh anymore. It was the best. Lately I’ve been feeling so grateful that I get to do what I do as a job. But some jobs I’m EXTRA grateful for and the box office receipts or rotten tomato score never really have anything to do with it #tbt 😌✌️💨

Our latest “Life Is Short” podcast guest @thelesliejordan has been an unmistakably unique and hilarious fixture on television for decades. But it is difficult to describe Leslie Jordan without eventually saying “you gotta just watch him in something!” And that might explain his recent surge in Instagram popularity. Because Leslie’s infectiously puckish spirit and wit are on full display every morning whether he’s recounting stories from his past or attempting to give a report on the day’s weather forecast. Leslie has been bringing millions of people (myself included) a steady helping of joy and mirth during these strange uncertain times. I so appreciate him and so loved getting to express that TO him on this podcast - and I know I speak for many people in the instacommunity (closing in on 4 million, at last count - followers earned the old fashioned, by being an honest, insightful, and truly entertaining story teller) - the truth is, we could all use a daily dose of @thelesliejordan. Thanks, Leslie 😌❤️

Most of my favorite roles in movies I’ve acted in have been cameos - they’re quick, fun and easy to shoot! Now there’s an app called @cameo which I just joined! I’m guessing it too is going to be quick, fun and easy to shoot. The best part is 100% of any money I make (75% of total) will go directly to @nokidhungry - an organization that supplies food to the nearly 1 in 7 kids in America who struggle with food insecurity.  I’ve been feeling immense gratitude for the things I have lately—including my health, my house, and my ability to eat whenever I want. @nokidhungry supplies meals to the over 22 million children in America who are not as lucky - kids who, in the past, have relied heavily on school lunches to fill the gap in their daily nutrition - lunches that, as you all know, will not be available to them in the coming months. So check out @cameo and let’s have some fun! Thank you 😌

Dr Dave gives us an update on the ongoing fight against COVID19 that he and his colleagues are bravely and tirelessly fighting. But they’re still contending with a shortage of personal protective equipment - Dr Kessler suggested people donate, if they can, to https://getusppe.org/give/ - a link that I’ll also put in my bio 👍😷

In January 1986, I was a 2nd grader at Riverfield Elementary School. That’s me in the #56 NY Giants jersey (it’s not actually Lawrence Taylor, for anyone studying it closely). The launching of the Challenger Space shuttle was an event we’d been following closely, as one of its crew members, Christa McAuliffe, was scheduled to become the first teacher in space. I’ll never forget that very sad day - it was the first time it really struck me how human life was fragile and susceptible to ending in a flash - even the lives of strong, impressive, heroic adults like Ms McAuliffe. Sitting here in quarantine and appreciating my own life that I’ve gotten to live so far and DEEPLY appreciative of the doctors, nurses and other heroic medical workers putting their own precious lives on the line today 😌🙏❤️ #tbt

Being gently cradled by @dkharbour... (the latest guest on “Life Is Short” podcast - link in bio!) is something we all might WANT right now but due to the need for social distancing, it’s not safe. This photo was taken pre social D-ing when David was still a safe harbor. But who could’ve foreseen the stranger things that’ve happened since this loving embrace occurred? David and I chat about the corona virus (in a very cavalier, early March-type way), his long career and sudden shot to fame (as the star of bingetastic @strangerthingstv), his upcoming role in @marvelstudios “Black Widow”, our mutual love of frogs and SO many things in between. David is a fascinating, funny, gentleman bear and I can’t wait to be socially near him again. I hope everyone is staying safe and at home, if that’s possible - and I’m so grateful to those for whom staying at home is not possible. Check out @nokidhungry for ways to help the most vulnerable during this crisis. And keep writing in- we love hearing from you “lifeisshort@wondery.com” 😌👍

A few weeks ago this would’ve looked like just a couple a’ nerds weirdly touching elbows but @billnye (my latest guest on “Life Is Short” podcast -link in bio) and iye were simply demonstrating how to greet one another during this Corona pandemic. NOW, thanks to the @who, we know that even elbow-bumping is too risky as it encroaches on the 6 ft perimeter we should be keeping as we try and #flattenthecurve of this virus. Now, more than ever, I’m so grateful to people like Bill who promote science and the importance of trusting the scientific community. Speaking of... Bill Nye, the Science Guy is now also a podcaster guy! He has a new podcast called “Science Rules! With Bill Nye” - please check it out. If a crisis like this reminds us of anything it’s that science DOES, in fact, rule. My deepest gratitude for everyone tackling this pandemic from the ER doctors and nurses to the people heeding the essential advice of the scientific community and socially distancing themselves - we are in this together and we will get through this together. Lots of love and healthy wishes to all of you. And thanks again to Bill Nye and ALL the Science guys and gals out there. 😌🙏🙏🙏💪

Paul has recently been cast in a string of high profile movies “I, Tonya”, “Blackkklansmen”, and the lead in “Richard Jewell” - because Spike Lee and Clint Eastwood knew what MANY people now know: that Paul is one of the best actors to come around in a long time. I love this episode so much. Hope you guys do too 😌🙏

The great @mirasorvino is our guest on the latest episode of “Life Is Short” (link in bio)! She’s a fearless activist, brilliant impressionist, mother of four and oh yeah SHE’S AN OSCAR WINNER! She is also one of the most intellectually intimidating and stimulating (👈best read in the voice of Walt Clyde Frazier) guests I’ve been lucky enough to talk to on this show. I was so riveted and moved by her experiences as a survivor of  Harvey Weinstein abuse and how she continues to struggle with the fallout. She’s also really funny and told great stories about how she developed her voice for two of her most beloved characters in “Mighty Aphrodite” and “Romy and Michelle’s High School Reunion”. And she speaks Mandarin!! She was fun, fascinating and inspiringly fearless. 😌💪
SO embarrassing when you leave the house with a hole in your pants! 🤦🏻‍♂️

I got to hang out with some funny and brilliantly creative kids for a few weeks while they politely tolerated my dumb jokes and klutzy bits. Were there “better” pics of me and @alecbaldwininsta (the latest guest on “Life Is Short” podcast -link in bio)? Yes. But none that so perfectly captured how I feel about him. He’s an actor I’ve admired since I was a kid but he also may be the funniest and most deft conversationalist I’ve ever had the pleasure of sitting down with on this show. A show in which Alec busts out some of my favorite impressions, some brilliant new ones I hadn’t heard, talks about doing Tennessee Williams and Shakespeare, about football, and growing up and now having kids of his own, and he shames me for asking him what his favorite movie is.  I didn’t want it to end but since he’s the hardest working man in show business, the father of several young children, and probably Batman... his time was, sadly, limited. But it was good while it lasted, which, like everything else, would sound much cooler if it came out of Alec’s mouth. *p.s. Something that often doesn’t get publicized about Alec’s life is how much money he donates to charity - mostly arts and literacy programs in and around NYC as well as sorely needed environmental efforts. Look up how much of his @capitalone ad money he donated, for example- his generosity is often overshadowed by other more tabloid-friendly stories. Just thought it was worth mentioning 😌✌️

Of all the good people I’ve met in this good place called earth, I don’t think it gets any better than @kristenanniebell - our latest guest on “Life Is Short” (link in bio). K Bell needs no introduction which makes writing this caption a little easier. She was kind enough to stop by for a long overdue catchup - during which we almost talk about her hugely successful career (from Veronica Mars to Frozen 2) but actually talk about her many foster dogs, her total lack of road rage, the secrets to a successful marriage (I was taking notes) and our friendship which has now spanned 15 years 🤯
2. I also bring up (too often)  the things we have in common - one being we both have terrible memories. Case in point, we both forgot that we had an onscreen romance as Supergirl and Robin in an admittedly forgettable movie (“Movie 43”).
3. Listeners to our show are well aware that I also am crazy about her husband @daxshepard (whose @armchairexppod really helped launch our show - for which I’ll forever be indebted to him)
4. Kristen introduced me to one of my favorite characters in the world - John C Reilly’s Dr Steve Brule. One of many reasons why, as I said, she’s the best. Thanks, Denny 😌🙏🍆

My Grandmother Jody is our VERY special guest on the latest episode of “Life Is Short” (link in bio) despite the fact that she’s 102 years old. She was born in 1917 - before the electric refrigerator and pop-up toasters were invented, before there were self-serving supermarkets, before the world’s first billionaire, before Nathan Hanweker sold the first hotdog at Coney Island, before we entered World War ONE, before Woodrow Wilson sent troops into Mexico to pursue Pancho Villa, before Daylight Savings Time went into effect and, as you can see, long long LONG before there was a “selfie”. Or a podcast. Or “the Orgasmatron” head scratcher (pic #2). I’m so grateful she can still participate in these new (probably VERY strange) innovations and that she’s still laughing - and making people around her laugh (I hope that now includes you!) Thanks for checking it out. And speaking of “thanks” - my brother @poodollar72 and I are immensely thankful that you listen to the show because we truly love doing it. And getting to spend your precious time doing what you love with PEOPLE you love is the best gift you could ask for because, as I HOPE we’ve established... life is short 😌🙏 #happythanksgivng

In addition to being surprisingly tall, Tim Robbins, our guest today on “Life Is Short” (link in bio) is unsurprisingly smart, thoughtful and a courageous social activist. And he was once in an obscure movie about some dudes in a prison. We talk about that underground cult classic, his drive to amplify the voices of marginalized people, and the benefits of being 6 ft 5 inches tall. We also talk about his new movie @darkwatersmovie starring another great artist/activist @markruffalo who plays Rob Bilott, a corporate defense attorney who takes on DuPont chemical and exposes their atrocious decades-long poisoning of our environment and the subsequent coverup. It’s riveting and important - can’t recommend enough. 👍♻️🌏
1. Our actual heights (with me slouching slightly, as I do)
2. Tim suggested I stand on a step so we looked the same height. 
3. I slouched more than usual so I’d look like his prepubescent son. 👨‍👦 Edit: in this episode we mention a friend of mine from childhood, Tim. Sadly, we just found out that Tim’s dad, Jim Schnurr passed away recently after suffering an injury from a bicycle accident years earlier. Jim sounded like he lived an incredible, accomplished life and donations in his honor can be made to @thereevefoundation to help find a cure for spinal chord injuries. Thanks 🙏✌️

In 1994 I was a wide-eyed teenager who’d just fallen head over heels in love with movies and the prospect of one day making a movie, when I saw “Clerks” - a movie that was basically about a convenience store clerk who had to go to work when he didn’t want to. It was hilarious and moving and all the things my favorite movies were AND, most importantly, it looked like it was made for the same amount of money I could MAYBE scrounge together (because it was). It made the idea of making movies or being in them instantly accessible - no longer a shameful little pipe dream I had but a potentially achievable goal. Years later the director of that movie would take me under his creative wing in a more direct way, putting me in several of his projects - the most formative and meaningful one being an insane experimental Human Centipede-esque romp called “Tusk” and I am forever changed because of it (in a MUCH more positive way than my character in that movie). @thatkevinsmith is our guest on today’s episode of “Life Is Short”. We talk about our experience working with one another and Kevin drops some beautifully articulate pearls about life, his creative history, and his very recent brush with death. It has been an honor to work with him over the years and, if nothing else, I’m always grateful to have the opportunity to thank him for always inviting me to play in his fun, weird sandbox. Hope you guy’s enjoy this episode (link in bio) - it’s a little longer than usual but Kevin is just too good at talking. 😘

1. When you’re making something as dark as “Tusk” was the only way to get through it, sanity-intact, is by laughing. Which we did...a LOT.
2. In addition to the many things I’m grateful to Kevin for, giving me the chance to act opposite the late GREAT legend, Michael Parks is at the top of the list.
3. We recorded this episode and an ep of Kevin’s “smodcast” at his home podcasting studio in LA. 
4. A bad picture of a very GOOD memory - the LA premiere of “Tusk” at the Vista Theatre in Los Feliz (one of my favorites)
5. I just GOT a home podcasting studio and this photo of us in our natural joyful working element shooting “Tusk” was the first thing I hung on the wall.

So honored to have @neildegrassetyson as my guest on the latest episode of “Life Is Short” (link in bio). Dr Tyson (or “Neil” as he amiably insisted I call him) is a brilliant astrophysicist, distinguished professor and writer, and long-time director of the Hayden Planetarium (or, as actress Hayden Panettiere probably calls it, The Hayden Panettierium) at The Rose Center For Earth and Space in NYC. We talk about EVERYTHING from the nature of the universe to a feud he had with Moby and his affection for Big Bird. It was a conversation I hoped would never end. Such a thrill. I hope you all enjoy it.

#tbt shooting “Strange Wilderness” w Jonah (link in bio) and the late GREAT Ernest Borgnine - who, despite being one of our most legendary screen actors and almost 90 years of age, was SO game to do dumb improvised bits with us young ding dongs. #tbt shooting “Accepted” and eating corn nuts w my pal @jonahhill (also my guest on the current episode of “Life Is Short” podcast - link in bio!).

In 2004 or ‘05 I guest starred on a funny but short-lived improvisational show that @_cherylhines produced called “Campus Ladies”. It was there that I witnessed the comedic genius of an unknown actor named @jonahhill. He had Vince Vaughn’s fearlessness, Don Rickles’s bite, and the mind of a brilliant Simpsons writer. It was a thing to behold and I couldn’t get enough of his company. We quickly became friends, then roommates and costars a few times over. Today, most of the world is familiar w Jonah’s talents and has seen his work in award-winning movies. On the latest episode of “Life Is Short” podcast (link in bio), we talk about how much has changed in his life and career since we met 15 years ago. But the best part was discovering how little has changed in the simple joy of sitting down and laughing with my old friend. It reminded me of some of my favorite moments in my life. I’ll be posting some old pictures of us from back in the day throughout the week 😘✌️

The first podcast I was ever on was my friend @annafaris’s “Unqualified”. I had so much fun that, years later, it inspired me to do “Life is Short” and my life is better and more fun for it. Uncle Dee and Uncle Dum

When the “Mac vs PC” commercials were running, my friend, James (on the right), convinced (dared) me to stand still, mannequin-style in the window of the #AppleStore on 9th ave in NYC. The guy on the left was a passerby who, with the help of James’s baiting, was struck by how lifelike the “Mac Guy mannequin” looked. He was inches from me, fogging the glass while carefully studying my face, when I suddenly and drastically dropped my arm and changed my facial expression to a big weird smile. He leapt backwards a good foot and a half, threw up his fists in a defensive stance and yelled “Ohhhh DAMN!” I still can’t believe I only did that once #tbt

Dearest residents Of Indianapolis! What do you have to do with a home for social orphans run by an order of  nuns in Granada, Nicaragua??? Well... if you come see me this weekend at @horrorhound (Indianapolis Convention Center) ALL the proceeds from any money you spend at my “station”... “booth” (?), minus booker + agent fees 🙄, will go directly to this incredible place. Nicaragua is a beautiful country inhabited by some of the loveliest people you’ll ever meet... Unfortunately, Nicaragua also contends with widespread poverty which has lead to rampant sex tourism (perpetrated mostly by Americans and Europeans). @thegirlshome provides a safe, educational, and happy haven for girls who are in DIRE need of such a place. So if you can’t make it to Indianapolis this weekend, check out their website and if you CAN and you happen to take a photo with me (even if it was by accident), please tag @girlshomenica or www.thegirlshome.com and help me spread the word about this home and it’s residents (whom I feel so fortunate to know). And, before you comment a version of “what about kids living in poverty in AMERICA??”, let me save you the time: I don’t consider a kid less deserving of a chance at a happy life because they happen to have been born in another place in the world ✌️(but if you’d like to explore some charities that provide support for American children in need, may I suggest @nokidhungry @covenant_house @sixdegreesofkb @thisisabouthumanity 👍🙏). Thank you! And hope to see you this weekend :)
Sometimes I DO believe in Heaven 😌

Had an epic, no-holds-barred PALE-OFF with my friend + former costar @jimgaffigan. He won... barely. In addition to being slightly more pale than me, he is much funnier and better at farting. On the latest episode of “Life Is Short” (link in bio) we talk about Jim’s brilliant comedy special (“Quality Time” on Amazon - the streaming platform, not the jungle in Brazil - I’ll only make THAT mistake once 🤦🏻‍♂️), raising FIVE kids vs zero kids, his wife’s harrowing battle with a brain tumor, and much much more. He’s truly one of the funniest people on the planet (maybe the whole galaxy?) and I hadn’t seen him much since we did “Going The Distance” together - so it was a true joy to spend some time with him. Hope you all enjoy it!

As a movie-loving child of the 80’s, I was introduced to Lea Thompson, our guest on today’s episode of “Life Is Short” (link in bio), at the age of seven and immediately fell in love. Years later I would work with her and come to know and respect her on a professional level (on @ryaneggold’s “Literally, Right Before Aaron” -3rd pic) and I would be forced to suppress that seven year old “Back To The Future”-obsessed kid because, well frankly, it would’ve gotten weird. On today’s episode, unfortunately for Lea, I can’t contain that kid and he’s on full awkward display. Fortunately for him and for me and for all of you, Lea was such a good sport - unbelievably gracious and honest and very very funny. Hope you all enjoy Lea and hearing me geek the F out.

He has one of the funniest, most fertile minds of anyone I’ve ever met, which is on full display here - as is his inspiringly empathetic worldview. We discuss, among other things, our love of basketball, Jesse’s lifelong struggles with anxiety, his disbelief that I’m not Jewish, and toxic masculinity through the lens of his great new movie “The Art Of Self-Defense” (currently in theatres + on demand). Also please check out www.middlewayhouse.org - a wonderful org that works to empower survivors of domestic abuse, sexual violence, and human trafficking through a wide range of supportive services and advocacy. 🙏

There are SO few people on earth I’d rather kibitz with than @officialfrandrescher. After you hear her on the latest episode of “Life Is Short” (link in bio), I think you’ll understand why. She is a force: quick-witted, self-reflective, ferociously courageous, and, as you can see from this picture, beautiful. Long before he was an avenger @renner4real was a karaoke superhero - he once sang a rendition of Bohemian Rhapsody that melted my brain. Here we are singing together (totally sober, as you can see) w our pal Leif at either Dimples or maybe the Gaslight in Santa Monica....it’s all a tad hazy except for Renner’s renndition of that nearly-impossible-to-sing-Queen song, THAT I remember every note of. 
Jeremy is finally sharing that gift with the world in the form of a few new songs he’s just released (on @spotify) as part of a collaboration with @jeep and the upcoming movie #ArticDogs. On the latest episode of “Life Is Short” podcast (link in bio) he discusses this new musical foray, his legendary karaoke past, his soon-to-be legendary acting future, and giving zero f*cks in g*neral. 
Side note: I saw Avengers Endgame the other day, after I’d sat down with Jeremy, and was truly blown away by it. It’s such a fun, impressive feat of storytelling and Renner carries the bulk of the story’s emotional weight - it’s as great as any performance you’ll see in any “Oscar-caliber” movie (maybe MORE impressive when you consider much of it was probably done in front of a green screen). It was great to see him and catch up. Hope you guys enjoy it. 🙏🏹

One of my favorite animals as a kid was the red-spotted newt. As an adult, I now feel very lucky to live in a place where they’re found in abundance in the wild. Like most amphibians, they are born in the water, eventually losing their gills and developing lungs. Unlike most amphibians, though, the Red-spotted newt has a sort of adolescent stage where they live on land for 2-3 years and are called “efts” by humans but probably normal names like “Carl” and “Stacy” by other efts. When they’re ready to become adults and have kids of their own, they return to the water, their skin becomes a drab olive-green and they get all slimy and THEN start making love. Sometimes I worry I’m still in my eft stage. 🤓

#tbt #for #the PODCAST listeners...
In the last episode (w @oliviawilde), there’s a story about my high school yearbook photo which, as discussed, is far more embarrassing than the regular embarrassing yearbook photo. The FIRST photo is the one my mother made me retake (at an extra cost, of course) because she (my own mother) was TOO EMBARRASSED TO FRAME THE OTHER ONE AND DISPLAY IT IN THE HOUSE. (As was I, so I’m grateful she went along with it.)
The second picture, for you podcast listeners, needs no further elaboration. You’re welcome and as therapeutic as this has all been, there’s a part of me that still can’t quite believe I’m voluntarily sharing this with more people...

1. Years ago my dear funny friend @oliviawilde asked me to play a part in her first short film “Free Hugs”. I knew then that one day she’d direct a great feature - I just didn’t know it’d be AS great as #booksmartmovie is. I’m insanely proud of her and grateful she sat down to talk to me about her new movie, her old name + many things in between on this week’s episode of “Life Is Short” - listen by following the link in my bio! #FemaleFilmmakerTuesday
2. “Free Hugs” group shot (I played a cross-eyed store clerk with a wispy mustache and an underbite named “Gerry”)
3. Olivia was actively involved in every aspect of the shoot (but did so respectfully without stepping on toes - quite a feat). Here she is applying makeup to an actor. 
4. Everyone liked her on set. Oftentimes background actors (or “extras”) get overlooked or dismissed - here she is directing some of them. Olivia treated everyone with respect. 
5. “Thrilled” to be at the Jets game. Not sure what year this was but, knowing the Jets, it could’ve been anytime in the last 5 decades. 
6. Olivia introduced me to political activism and Honey Badger videos in 2007. 
7. Goofing around with Sam Rockwell and Jeremy Renner. Go see #booksmartmovie this Friday May 24th - it’s easily my favorite movie of the year!

This was from a pilot I did a few years back called “Sober Companion” with the crazy funny and delectable @friedgold (in case any laaaaadies were interested in following my new page!). I don't post this to prove anything, or to try and make people believe I love my wife, I simply think it's an honoring thing to do, publicly acknowledging your significant other!  Its like we're all okay with acknowledging an achievement or award, but think there has to be something shady about saying something publicly about the one you love. I have nothing to prove by saying I love my wife. I just think there is power in putting ur wife on a pedestal! I like to make my wife feel special and valued, Ive done a lot of cool things but I dont think anything comes close to as cool as that
